English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>!
I saw the most peculiar person on TV.
One head, one body and\ntwo legs just like everyone else…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 똑같이 머리도 하나, 몸도\n하나, 다리도 두 개였지만…

English (United States)(en-US): But their neck was long as a pipe,\nand their head as small as a pea.
Their body was bloated and\nround like a beach ball,
and their legs were like twigs\na second away from snapping.
And! And!
They were a most fruity and\nrefreshing shade of pink!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아주 상큼한 맛이 나는 분홍빛을 띄고 있었어!

English (United States)(en-US): Um… I don't follow. You said they were human?
Could you draw them for me?
Hmm... Hmm! I’m not really a painter…
How about this?
They looked like this.
I can’t recreate that beautiful pink…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그의 아름다운 분홍빛이\n결여되어 있다는 것만 제외하면…

English (United States)(en-US): but I guess this will do.
Where on earth do these people come from?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이런 인간은 어디에 사는 어떤 인간이야?

English (United States)(en-US): Haha, Dot! That’s not a person!\nThat’s what we call a ‘flamingo’.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하하, 뭉치! 그건 인간이 아니야!\n‘플라밍고’라는 새를 본 것 같은데?

English (United States)(en-US): A flamingo? So they aren’t human?
Well, this is embarrassing.
♫ I wonder how, I wonder why ♫
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ♫ I wonder how, I wonder why ♫

English (United States)(en-US): ♫ Yesterday, you told me 'bout the blue, blue sky ♫
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ♫ Yesterday, you told me 'bout the blue, blue sky ♫

English (United States)(en-US): ♫ And all that I can see is just a yellow lemon tree ♫
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ♫ And all that I can see is just a yellow lemon tree ♫

English (United States)(en-US): Is that a new song you learned?|I see a great singer in the making.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치, 새로 배운 노래야?|멋진 가수의 새싹이 자라고 있군.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, it’s called “Lemon Tree.”
The song is called “Lemon Tree”,\nand it’s going to be my ticket to stardom.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 날 팝 스타로 만들어 줄 이 곡은 \n“레몬 트리”라는 이름을 가지고 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m not sure what the lyrics\nare about but it sounds nice!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 가사가 무슨 뜻인진\n잘 모르겠지만 듣기 좋아!

English (United States)(en-US): I like lemons. They smell\nlike… sharp sparkles!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 레몬이 좋아. 꼭…\n날카롭게 반짝이는 맛이잖아!

English (United States)(en-US): You may be talking about the taste “sour.”
Also, um… I’ve heard the lemons\nin the lyrics symbolize melancholy?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고, 음… 사실 노래 가사 속\n레몬은 우울을 상징할걸?

English (United States)(en-US): What?!
Oh wow. I didn’t even notice. I didn’t\ncatch any of that on my tongue.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우와. 눈치조차 못 챘어. 혀끝에\n어떠한 감각도 없었단 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Why?
Is it because lemons are sour,\nor because they’re yellow?
Well, one time while gazing up at the sun\nI wanted to be in its benevolent embrace
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 으음, 한 번은 태양을 올려다보며\n그의 자애로운 온기에 안겨 있고 싶어져서

English (United States)(en-US): so I furtively rubbed my\ncheek against its surface,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 햇살 표면에 내 볼을 슬며시\n부비적거려 본 적이 있었는데,

English (United States)(en-US): but its lemon-yellow rays beat down\non me and it thundered at me,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그는 레몬과 같은 노란빛의 햇살로\n나를 따갑게 내리쬐며 호통을 쳤지.

English (United States)(en-US): "How dare you!” And I… I had no choice\nbut to flee into the damp shadows.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): “감히 네가 어디를!” 난 그저… 축축한\n그림자 속으로 도망칠 수밖에 없었어.

English (United States)(en-US): Lemons must be\nthe fruit of rejection.
Mm…
Different experiences make us think\na certain way about certain things.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 제각각의 경험은 특정한 것에 대해\n특정한 방식으로 생각하게 할 때가 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): It's because memories are subjective!
Subjective?
See, you feel a sense of\nrejection from lemons.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 봐, 레몬을 생각하면 뭉치는\n거부당하는 느낌이 들잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): But some people feel\ndifferently about it.
Really? Wait, what do\nyou think of lemons?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 정말? 잠깐, 그럼 <nickname>은\n레몬에 대해 어떻게 생각하는데?

English (United States)(en-US): To me, lemons are…
Huh.
I understand. Lemons really\ncould be many things.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이해했어. 레몬은 정말\n수많은 것들이 될 수 있겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): So this singer must have had\na gloomy experience with lemons.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그럼 이 가수는 레몬과\n관련된 나쁜 일을 겪었겠구나.

English (United States)(en-US): Perhaps, maybe.
Hm…
I wonder what made lemons\ntaste like melancholy for this person.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 왜 이 사람의 레몬은\n우울한 맛이 나게 되었을까?

English (United States)(en-US): Ah, I think I see it.
Maybe he had a lemon drop in his mouth\nthe last time he ever saw his best friend.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어쩌면 가장 친한 친구를 마지막으로 봤을 때\n하필이면 레몬 사탕을 물고 있었을 수도 있겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe he once bit into a rotten lemon,\ngifted to him by a bunch of bullies.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어쩌면 못된 녀석들이 쥐여 준 썩은 레몬을\n 베어 문 적이 있었을지도 모르지.

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe he was the sibling of a murder victim \nwho was found with a bloody lemon in their hand.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어쩌면 피투성이 레몬을 손에 쥔 채 발견된\n 살해 피해자의 가족이었을지도.

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe…
Maybe…
Maybe.
Today I looked down at a dark red,\nsour blob of jam on the sidewalk,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오늘은 도시 바닥에 떨어진,\n누군가의 샌드위치에서 흘러 나왔을

English (United States)(en-US): that might have fallen out ofvsomeone’s sandwich, and thought,
‘I was born from something sort of\nlike that… dark and sticky and inedible;’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘나도 비슷할지 모르는 잼 덩어리에서\n태어났는데… 검고 끈적이고 먹을 수 없고’

English (United States)(en-US): ‘a putrid kind of jam.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘아무래도 역한 맛이 날 것 같은 잼.’

English (United States)(en-US): And then I blinked, and I was sucked into it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 생각하며 눈 깜빡 감았다 떴는데\n그 속으로 빨려들어가 버렸어.

English (United States)(en-US): Into a nightmare of a world.
It was red all over, like looking\nthrough red cellophane.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 붉은 셀로판지로 바라본 것처럼,\n모든 것이 붉었고.

English (United States)(en-US): (Picture blood.)|(Picture fruit juice.)
It was like being inside an ancient myth.
A giant lay on the ground,\nstabbed by a brave warrior’s sword.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 용맹한 전사의 칼에 찔려\n죽은 거인이 누워 있었어.

English (United States)(en-US): Its bloodshot eyes gazed\nat the red, rancid stream
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그는 핏발 선 눈을 하고, 자기 목에서\n솟구치는 시뻘겋고 비릿한 물줄기를

English (United States)(en-US): spurting from its throat.
A violent, yet silent red.
Everyone cheered at the giant’s\ndeath but it remained mute.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 모두가 거인의 죽음에 환호했지만\n오직 그만은 말이 없었지.

English (United States)(en-US): It looked at the roaring warrior and\nthe worshipping townsfolk, and said—
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그는 가슴을 내밀고 포효하는 전사와\n그를 숭배하는 마을 사람들을 바라보다가,

English (United States)(en-US): I never wanted to be born so big.
One day I’ll be reborn as a small\nraspberry. Mama. Mama. It hurts.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다음에는 아주 작고 올망졸망한\n산딸기로 태어나야지. 엄마. 엄마. 아파요.

English (United States)(en-US): Mama. I’m scared.
— and slipped and fell down the cliff.
Oh.
Oh.
That day on the moon, staring into\nspace and awaiting my death sentence,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 사실 달에서의 그날, 우주를 바라보며\n사형 집행을 기다리던 그날

English (United States)(en-US): I was that giant.
A giant falling into space.
I know its fear. Its sorrow,\nits disorientation,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그의 공포를 알아. 그의 설움을, 혼란을,

English (United States)(en-US): the feel of the darkness\ncrawling in the thick void.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 짙은 허공 속 우글거리던\n암흑의 감각을 알아.

English (United States)(en-US): I never wanted to be born in that\npitch black pit of all places, either.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 저도 그 시커먼 구덩이 속에서만큼은\n태어나고 싶지 않았는데 말이에요.

English (United States)(en-US): I wanted to be round and\npretty, like a color, like a dream.
I really really did.
I looked at the space surrounding\nme without no one to hold on to.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 붙잡을 사람 하나 없이\n우주를 바라만 바라만 보았어.

English (United States)(en-US): And like the giant staring at the rancid\nred stream with its bloodshot eyes,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 핏발 선 눈을 하고, 목에서 솟구치는 시뻘겋고\n 비릿한 물줄기를 바라보던 거인처럼

English (United States)(en-US): I tried to stomach everything\nI felt in a single swallow.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 모든 모든 마음을 한입에\n삼켜 보려 노력하면서.

English (United States)(en-US): It was like being inside a mortar\nmade of steel, in a jam factory.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어느 잼 공장의 철로 된\n절구통 속이었던 것 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): A raspberry, halfway crushed,
with bloodshot eyes gazed\nat the red, rancid stream
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 핏발 선 눈을 하고, 내장에서\n솟구치는 시뻘겋고 비릿한 물줄기를

English (United States)(en-US): spurting from its intestines.
A violent, yet silent red.
The pestle went thump, thump, thump, thump,\nand the raspberry said—
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 절구는 일정하게 쿵 쿵 쿵 쿵 쿵\n내려찍혔고 산딸기는

English (United States)(en-US): I never wanted to be born so sweet.
One day I’ll be reborn as a bitter giant. \nMama. Mama. It hurts.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다음에는 아주 씁쓸한 맛이 나는 거인으로\n태어나야지. 엄마. 엄마. 아파요.

English (United States)(en-US): Mama. I’m scared.
and was thrown into the pot as jam.
Oh.
That day on the moon, staring into space \nand awaiting my death sentence,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 사실 달에서의 그날, 우주를\n바라보며 사형 집행을 기다리던 그날

English (United States)(en-US): I was that raspberry.
A raspberry being crushed and crushed.
I know its fear. Its sorrow, is disorientation, the feel \nof the darkness that crawled in the thick void.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그의 공포를 알아. 그의 설움을, 혼란을, 짙은 \n허공 속 우글거리던 암흑의 감각을 알아.

English (United States)(en-US): I never wanted to be born in that\npitch black pit of all places, either.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나도 그 시커먼 구덩이 속에서만큼은\n태어나고 싶지 않았는데 말이에요.

English (United States)(en-US): I wanted to be round and pretty,\nlike a color, like a dream.
I really really did.
I looked at the space surrounding\nme with no one to hold on to.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 붙잡을 사람 하나 없이\n우주를 바라만 바라만 보았어.

English (United States)(en-US): And like the raspberry staring at the\nrancid red stream with bloodshot eyes,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 핏발 선 눈으로, 내장에서 솟구치는 시뻘겋고\n 비릿한 물줄기를 바라보던 산딸기처럼

English (United States)(en-US): tried to stomach every single\nthing I felt in a single swallow.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 모든 모든 모든 마음을\n한입에 삼켜 보려 노력하면서.

English (United States)(en-US): Hello.
Nice to see you again.
Did you know,
I come from the moon?
The dark side of the moon,\nin fact, that can’t be seen from Earth.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지구에선 보이지 않는,\n달의 어두운 뒤편에서 왔어.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m glad to be here, to\nhave met <nickname> and you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 이곳에 온 게 참 좋아. 너와\n<nickname>를 알게 되었다는 것도.

English (United States)(en-US): It feels like a dream I don’t want to wake\nfrom, or sweet ripples embracing me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 벗어나고 싶지 않은 꿈결 같고,\n다정히 안겨드는 물결 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): But sometimes, in the middle of\nthe night… the moon visits my mind.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런데 아주 가끔, 이따금의 한밤중에…\n달이 내 마음에 찾아올 때가 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): The dark side of the moon,\nthat can’t be seen from Earth.
I look to my very own moon then.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그럴 때면 난 나만의 달을 바라봐

English (United States)(en-US): That round lamp over there.\nMy own personal moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 저기 동그란 전등 말이야.\n오직 나를 위한, 나만의 달.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s not as gray or cratered\nas where I came from.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 시초지만큼 색이 어둡거나\n구덩이가 많진 않아.

English (United States)(en-US): In fact, it’s nothing like it.
This lamp is more like how\nthe moon looks from Earth:
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이 조명은… 지구에서 보이는\n달과 더 닮았을 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Bright and glowing.
But I still treasure it.
You see, it still reminds me\nof the moon that I know.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 조금도 닮지 않았지만, 그 자체만으로\n내가 아는 나의 달을 떠올리게 하니까.

English (United States)(en-US): Everyone else here\nsees the shining front,
but only I know the\nother side of the moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오직 나만이 달의 뒤편,\n그 어두운 이면을 아니까.

English (United States)(en-US): Filled with dust and filth,\nthe pitiful and soiled,
but the moon nonetheless.
That’s the moon that\nI know and remember.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그게 바로 내가 알고 기억하는 달이야.

English (United States)(en-US): My moon. And….
Their moon. Those with their\nwarmth and wounds.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나를 처음으로 알아 주었던, 상처 깊고\n따뜻한 이들… 내 첫 친구들의 달.

English (United States)(en-US): That’s the moon that\nI know and remember.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래서 너와 이 전등을 나누고 싶어.

English (United States)(en-US): It can be our little moon now.
